title: Build Your First Website Project
description: Learn project structure by building a real website from scratch using terminal commands

steps.title: Step 1: Understanding Project Structure
steps.content:
Before we write code, we need to understand how files are organized.

**Every web project needs:**
- üìÅ A **root folder** (home for your project)
- üìÑ **index.html** (your main HTML file)
- üìÑ **style.css** (your CSS stylesheet)
- üìÅ Optional folders like `images/`, `js/`, etc.

**Why does structure matter?**
- Keeps files organized
- Makes collaboration easier
- Industry standard practice
- Easier to find and fix bugs

Let's build this structure using **terminal commands** - the way professional developers work!

task.instruction: Click "Next" when you're ready to create your project folder!

steps.title: Step 2: Create Project Folder
steps.content:
Let's create a folder for your project using the `mkdir` command.

**What is `mkdir`?**
- Stands for "**M**a**k**e **Dir**ectory"
- Creates a new folder
- Used in: Windows (PowerShell), Mac, Linux

**Syntax:**
```
mkdir folder-name
```

You can use the provided name or customize it!

task.instruction: Create a folder called 'my-first-website' (or choose your own name):
hints: Use letters, numbers, hyphens, or underscores only
No spaces in folder names
Examples: my-website, first-project, portfolio-site

steps.title: Step 3: Navigate Into Your Folder
steps.content:
Now let's "enter" your project folder using the `cd` command.

**What is `cd`?**
- Stands for "**C**hange **D**irectory"
- Moves you into a folder
- Like double-clicking a folder in File Explorer

**Syntax:**
```
cd folder-name
```

This changes your working directory so files you create go inside this folder.

hints: Type 'cd' followed by your folder name
Tab completion works in real terminals!

steps.title: Step 4: Create index.html
steps.content:
Every website needs an HTML file! Let's create `index.html` using the `touch` command.

**What is `touch`?**
- Creates an empty file
- Mac/Linux command (Windows: `type nul >`)
- Fast way to create files from terminal

**Why "index.html"?**
- Web servers look for `index.html` by default
- It's the "home page" of your site
- Industry naming convention

**Syntax:**
```
touch filename.html
```

hints: Exactly as shown: touch index.html
File extension matters: .html

steps.title: Step 5: Create style.css
steps.content:
Now let's add a CSS file for styling.

**What is CSS?**
- Controls how your website looks (colors, fonts, layout)
- Keeps styling separate from HTML (good practice!)
- File extension: `.css`

We'll use the same `touch` command.

hints: Same command, different filename
Don't forget the .css extension

steps.title: Step 6: View Your File Structure
steps.content:
Let's see what we've created using the `ls` command.

**What is `ls`?**
- Stands for "**L**i**s**t"
- Shows all files and folders in current directory
- Like viewing files in File Explorer
- Mac/Linux: `ls`, Windows: `dir`

**Your project should now look like:**
```
my-first-website/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ style.css
```

hints: Just type 'ls' (lowercase)
You should see 2 files listed

steps.title: Step 7: Add HTML Content
steps.content:
Now let's add code to `index.html`! In a real terminal, you'd type `code index.html` to open an editor.

Our built-in editor will pop up below. Write a basic HTML structure.

task.instruction: Open index.html in editor and add basic HTML:
task.starter:
Welcome to My Website!

This is my first web project.
hints: Notice the <link> tag connecting to style.css
Every HTML page needs <!DOCTYPE html>
Content goes inside <body> tags

steps.title: Step 8: Add CSS Styling
steps.content: Time to make it look good! Open `style.css` and add some styles.

hints: CSS rules have format: selector { property: value; }
Notice how we style body, h1, and p separately
Colors can be hex codes (#2563eb) or names (blue)

steps.title: Step 9: Preview Your Website
steps.content:
Let's see your creation! In a real terminal, you'd type `open index.html` to view it in a browser.

Our live preview will show your website below.

task.instruction: Open your website in the browser:
hints: Your HTML and CSS should work together
If styling doesn't show, check the <link> tag
Try changing colors in style.css and re-save!

steps.title: Step 10: Congratulations! üéâ
steps.content:
You've successfully built your first website project using professional workflows!

**What you learned:**
- ‚úÖ Creating project folders (`mkdir`)
- ‚úÖ Navigating directories (`cd`)
- ‚úÖ Creating files (`touch`)
- ‚úÖ Listing files (`ls`)
- ‚úÖ Opening files in editor (`code`)
- ‚úÖ Previewing in browser (`open`)
- ‚úÖ Project structure best practices
- ‚úÖ Connecting HTML to CSS

**Next Steps:**
- Download your project as a ZIP
- Try adding more pages (about.html, contact.html)
- Create an images/ folder and add pictures
- Learn JavaScript to add interactivity

**Professional Tip:**
Real developers use these same commands every day. You're building the right habits from the start!

task.instruction: Click "Download Project" to save your work, or click "Complete" to continue learning!
